I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-
based loan to the Republic of the Philippines for subprogram 3 of the Facilitating Youth School-
to-Work Transition Program. 
 
2.  The program will enhance the employability of youth1 by shortening the school-to-work 
transition for at-risk young Filipinos.2 In addition, the program contains measures that will help 
counter the effects of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic on the broader labor market 
both now and into the post-COVID-19 recovery.3 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  The Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the programmatic 
approach and loan for subprogram 1 on 23 May 2017.4 Subprogram 1 supported the Government 
of the Philippines in restructuring public employment services and strengthening labor market 
activation and skills development programs. This provided a foundation for subprogram 2, which 
was approved on 3 December 2019 together with the addition of subprogram 3.5 Subprogram 2: 
(i) enhanced the ability of youth to secure long-term employment by introducing new labor market 
programs and training opportunities; and (ii) strengthened labor market policies. Building on the 
reform  measures  achieved  under  subprogram  1  and  2,  subprogram  3  provides  improved 
employment opportunities for youth and includes direct responses to—and innovative features 
designed to overcome—the challenges posed by the unprecedented community quarantine 
measures used to constrain the COVID-19 pandemic. The program also reflects the government’s 
commitment  to  gender  equality  in  its  pandemic  response,  given  that  women  have  been 
particularly affected. A post-program partnership framework (P3F) for 2021–2022 will ensure 
program sustainability and provide a foundation for the next program on post-COVID-19 business 
and employment recovery planned for 2022 (footnote 3). Key accomplishments of the program 
are summarized in the box. 
 
Box: Key Accomplishments 
 
Programmatic Approach 
•  To help Filipinos find employment and improve their skills, the number of Public Employment 
Service Offices (PESOs) was expanded to almost 1,500, of which one-third are fully functional, 
with more than 4,000 additional barangay-based PESOs enlisted to assist with coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) recovery efforts. 
•  To help young Filipinos bridge the school-to-work divide, JobStart Philippines has served almost 
20,000 youth, more than half of whom are women, with a 67% placement rate. 
•  The Special Program for Employment of Students has provided first jobs for more than 393,500 
young Filipinos, over half of whom are women.

Box: Key Accomplishments 
 
•  The program’s gender focus has been progressively strengthened and by 2022 will reduce the 
female youth unemployment rate by 5.2 percentage points from its pandemic high; reduce the 
female not in employment, education, or training rate by 5.7 percentage points from the “without 
the program” estimate and increase female technical and vocational education and training 
graduates by 0.3 million, increasing their income by about $157 million. 
 
Subprogram 3 
•  A ₱1 billion scholarship fund was established to help young Filipinos attend technical and 
vocational education and training programs, with a specific focus on women. 
•  A systematic approach has been introduced to identify and guide jobseekers to “green jobs.” 
•  An unemployment insurance scheme was activated and funded and has begun paying claims. 
•  Referenced and aligned the Philippine Qualification Standards with the ASEAN Qualifications 
Reference Framework, thereby improving regional worker mobility. 
 
COVID-19 Response 
•  The program has provided dedicated support to displaced overseas Filipino workers, 41.6% of 
whom are women, through group livelihood programs to help them engage in economic activities. 
•  The program has utilized technology to provide continuing access to labor market facilitation 
programs and to better target COVID-19 pandemic-related social assistance programs. 
 
Post-Program Partnership Framework 
•  A total of 560 PESOs will be fully independent and functional by 2022. 
•  The Department of Labor and Employment will develop a new 5-year strategy for the national 
rollout of JobStart. 
•  Enterprise-led learning networks will be established with at least four industry networks.

4.  Development problem. Until 2020, the Philippines was one of the best-performing 
economies  in  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  region.  Prudent 
macroeconomic  policy  supported  economic  growth, 6  and  sound  fiscal  and  public  debt 
management ensured that the country’s debt profile remained sustainable.7 Gross domestic 
product grew by an average 6.6% per annum during 2015–2019, with recent strength (2018 and 
2019) attributable to the government’s signature “Build Build Build” infrastructure program.8 The 
national poverty rate declined from 23.5% in 2015 to 16.7% in 2018. Likewise, from 2015 to 2019, 
the national unemployment rate declined from 6.3% to 5.1% and the underemployment rate 
declined from 18.5% to 14.0%, representing historic lows. Even the stubbornly high rates of youth 
unemployment, and youth not in employment, education, or training (NEET) declined during this 
period (figures 1 and 2). Owing to the strength of the government’s labor market activation 
programs, youth unemployment had declined to below 15% by 2019 and the persistent positive 
gap between the unemployment rates of young women and men had narrowed. At the same time, 
however, the level of youth NEET in the Philippines was the highest in Southeast Asia in 2018 
and varied considerably across gender, education level, and regions.9 While also narrowing, in 
2019 the female NEET rate (24.1%) was more than 10 percentage points higher than the male 
NEET rate (13.7%) nationwide and 13 percentage points higher in rural areas. At least one in four 
young Filipino women was not active in the labor market or in paid work, which contributed to the 
higher poverty rate among women. High NEET rates are due primarily to the long and uncertain 
transition from education to employment.10 It takes a college graduate 2 years and a high school

5.  Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Then, in 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic and the 
related  community  quarantine  measures drove  the  economy  into  recession  for  the  first 
time since the  Asian  financial  crisis  of  1998.  Gross  domestic  product  contracted by 9.5%, 
reversing gains in reducing unemployment and poverty. In fact, the unemployment rate peaked at 
17.2% in April 2020 during the strictest lockdown, when almost one in every two Filipinos was not 
economically active, before easing to 8.7% in October 2020. Moreover, the youth, and young 
women in particular, were the first and most affected as they tended to work in the most adversely 
impacted sectors, including wholesale and retail trade, accommodation and food services, and 
manufacturing. This disparate impact is similar to the experience globally where 510 million, or 
40% of all employed women, work in these hard-hit sectors.13 Overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) 
were similarly affected, and again the largest impact fell on women. Of the 2.2 million OFWs 
deployed in 2019, 1,233,000 (56%) were women and 969,000 (44%) were men. About 57.5% of 
the deployed OFWs work in elementary occupations or in services and sales, and almost 80% of 
the OFWs in these sectors are women. Employment prospects for the youth, and especially young 
women, remain bleak as companies tend to freeze hiring or hire experienced workers over recent 
graduates for the fewer available jobs.14 In fact, the youth unemployment rate worsened from 
13.6% in January 2020 to 19.8% in January 2021 (equivalent to 1.4 million jobless young workers) 
and is projected to increase to as high as 22.5% by 2022.15

7.  Binding constraints in the COVID-19 pandemic context. Through the program, the 
government was following a well-sequenced plan to address the initial set of binding constraints 
by expanding physical access to labor activation programs and improving their quality, improving 
access to skills development and higher education, and establishing a solid legal framework to 
facilitate employment. While the original binding constraints remain valid, addressing them has 
become more challenging because of the COVID-19 pandemic and the ensuing quarantine 
restrictions. After consultations with the government, the development constraints have been 
modified to reflect  the following  challenges  and  emerging  priorities: (i)  capacity  to  provide 
innovative employment facilitation services locally is limited; (ii) skills development and training 
opportunities are not sufficient relative to the need; and (iii) labor market policies and regulations 
require further strengthening and new provisions are needed to address pandemic-related job 
losses and issues, including those specific to women.16 
 
8.  Capacity to provide employment facilitation services locally is limited. Under the 
program, the number of Public Employment Service Offices (PESOs) and their inventory and 
quality of services have grown and improved. However, the PESO network is not yet of sufficient 
size and reach, which reduces access, especially for young women in rural areas. Less than one-
third of job seekers used public employment services to find jobs, and most of those who did were 
living in urban areas. This is because PESOs in cities are more likely to be fully functional than 
those in municipalities. Therefore, more PESOs should be established, operationalized, and 
institutionalized across localities nationwide to facilitate employment and increase access to their 
services.17 Measures  should  also  be  introduced  to  promote  more  consistent  delivery  of 
employment facilitation services. The COVID-19 pandemic has magnified these challenges in the 
following ways: (i) there are significantly more job seekers than before and (ii) many public 
employment  facilitation  programs  relied  heavily  on  in-person  contact  and  were  suspended 
because of quarantine restrictions. There is a need to adjust these programs to sustain progress 
while  minimizing  physical  contact  to  reach  the  newly  unemployed,  as  well  as  
at-risk youth and women in remote areas. Services offered by PESOs should also be expanded 
to provide specialized assistance to first-time job seekers and to newly displaced and vulnerable 
workers who are at risk of falling into long-term unemployment, including the roughly half-million 
displaced OFWs, 41.6% of whom are women.

9.  Skills development and training opportunities are not sufficient relative to the need. 
Subprograms 1 and 2 have done much to improve access to training and address job–skill 
mismatches. Yet many workers, especially young workers and women, still do not have the 
relevant  skills  required  in  the  modern  workplace.  These  mismatches  persist  because  of 
inadequate  funding  for  training  and  scholarship  programs;  weak  labor  market  information 
systems; and limited use of the private sector and technology to support education, training, and 
outreach. The COVID-19 pandemic has magnified these skill mismatches as companies are now 
relying more on technology. Women have been disproportionately affected by these disruptions 
because of the digital gender divide, gendered job displacement, and an increased care-giving 
burden arising from the lockdowns. There is an urgent need to: (i) upskill, reskill, and diversify 
worker skills; and (ii) promote specialization to cater to higher value-added services given the 
ongoing transformation of jobs, as well as future skills needs. The Philippine Qualifications 
Framework (PQF) has been formally approved, but there is a critical need to implement the 
framework so that graduates of technical-vocational-livelihood training and senior high school can 
pursue higher education by receiving recognition for their prior learning. The government should 
also ensure that the Philippine qualifications mirror the ASEAN standards to increase the mobility 
of and demand for Filipino workers. With the government focused on making the post-pandemic 
recovery green, new and higher-paying job opportunities could be created for displaced workers, 
and women in particular, but not enough effort has been made to identify and catalog this 
emerging demand. 
 
10.  Labor policies and regulations require further strengthening and new provisions 
are needed to address pandemic-related issues. Robust labor market policies provide vital 
support for long-term employment and take on increased importance during economic downturns. 
Recognizing this relationship, the government established the foundation for several support 
mechanisms during subprograms 1 and 2, but these reforms were incomplete. For example, a 
legal framework for an unemployment insurance scheme was adopted to provide a social safety 
net to cushion workers from sudden economic shocks. This scheme now needs to be funded and 
activated. This type of institutional support is particularly important during the pandemic when a 
large percentage of the labor force is vulnerable to job and income losses and is at a heightened 
risk of being pushed back into poverty. Ongoing efforts to protect laborers from abusive practices 
need to be maintained but also modified to recognize the challenges to providing support while 
social distancing. For example, occupational health and safety protocols could be enhanced to 
promote  safe  and  secure  working  environments,  including  minimum  health  and  sanitation 
standards to be observed, and key pandemic response measures such as calibrated maximum 
occupancy levels which will help facilitate the restoration of pre-pandemic employment levels. 
Ongoing efforts to establish a dispute resolution mechanism related to unfair labor practices 
should be strengthened, but also modified so that it can be accessed through a contactless 
channel. Beyond the pandemic, this will also open access to rural areas and women by removing 
the requirement to travel to a physical location to file a grievance. Finally, the unprecedented 
effects  of  the  pandemic  have  given  rise  to  the  need  for  targeted  interventions  for  those 
disproportionally affected. A half-million displaced OFWs, 41.6% of which are women from highly 
affected sectors need help so that they can reintegrate into the domestic economy.

B.  Policy Reform, ADB’s Value Addition, and Sustainability 
 
12.  Government’s  reform  agenda.  The  Philippine  Development  Plan  places  a  strong 
emphasis on accelerating human capital development to promote inclusive growth and to reduce 
poverty and income inequality, based on three priority areas: (i) increasing the income-earning 
ability of Filipinos by improving their employability through better employment facilitation services, 
(ii) expanding on-the-job training, and (iii) helping women overcome barriers to participation in the 
labor market. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the government passed the Bayanihan to 
Heal as One Act in March 2020 and the Bayanihan to Recover as One Act in September 2020 to 
mitigate the adverse socioeconomic impacts of the pandemic. The government also drafted the 
National Employment Recovery Strategy, 2020–2022 with four pillars: (i) stimulating the economy 
and employment; (ii) supporting enterprises, jobs, and income; (iii) protecting workers in the 
workplace; and (iv) trusting social dialogue to encourage innovative solutions.21 
 
13.  Programmatic approach and budget support. The Facilitating Youth School-to-Work 
Transition  Program  has  adopted  a  programmatic  approach  using  policy-based  loans  and 
technical assistance (TA) to support the government’s reform agenda (footnotes 33 and 34). This 
approach  provides  flexibility  and  enables  mid-course  design  changes,  which  is  particularly 
important during highly fluid economic crises such as the one caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. 
The TA helps the government meet capacity-building needs and address policy issues that have 
a bearing on strategy decisions. 
 
14.  Reform accomplishments. During the processing of subprogram 2, the government 
agreed to carry out 17 indicative policy actions as the basis for subprogram 3. After the onset of 
the pandemic, ADB worked with the government to adjust the program to provide an appropriate 
response. While the basis of the program remains sound, modifications were made to de-
emphasize new reforms dependent on in-person contacts and to maximize the use of science, 
technology, and innovation in delivering existing employment activation and training programs.22 
Two indicative policy actions—statistical profiling to rationalize existing labor market activation 
initiatives and the establishment of enterprise-led learning networks—were overtaken by the 
pandemic and became less relevant or difficult to implement. Two new policy actions were added 
as a direct response to the pandemic. These include initiatives to provide financial relief to support 
first-time job seekers, and to require employers to develop and implement programs to prevent 
discrimination and harassment in the workplace. Further, several policy actions were modified to 
better reflect the government’s commitment to climate resilience, which is also a part of its post-
pandemic recovery initiatives. Subprogram 3 now contains 17 policy actions, all of which have 
been accomplished.23 These changes did not result in any significant alteration to the program’s 
intended outcome or impact (para. 26).

24.  Lessons  learned.  ADB’s  partnership  with  the  government  and  engagement  in 
employment  facilitation  and  the  education  sector  have  informed  the  program.  First,  youth 
unemployment is a complex structural issue needing strong commitment and support from both

provides the required comprehensive approach. Second, given the high sensitivity of youth 
unemployment to external shocks, such as pandemics or disasters triggered by natural hazards, 
the government needs to remain flexible and tailor reforms to meet the specific needs of the 
situation (e.g., by sectors, age groups, or gender).  Performance targets and reform actions 
should be reviewed and adjusted throughout the program to ensure their appropriateness and

addition, the program highlighted the overwhelming disparate impact the pandemic has had on

C.  Expected Outcome of the Reforms 
 
26.  Impact  of  the  reforms.  The  program  is  aligned  with  the  country’s  overarching 
development objective of increasing the wage employment rate of the country’s youth. Just before 
the pandemic, most outcome indicator targets had already been achieved. As of October 2019, 
the NEET rate was 17.2%, below the target of 19.4%, and the youth unemployment rate was 
12.9%, below the target of 13.1%. However, by January 2021, the unprecedented effects of the 
COVID-19  pandemic  had  caused  the  NEET  rate  to  increase  to  19.4%  and  the  youth 
unemployment rate to rise to 19.8%. The government has acknowledged the impact of the 
pandemic  and  revised  its  targets:  the  NEET  rate  upward  to  17%–19%  and  the  youth 
unemployment rate upward to 20.5%–22.5%, both by 2022.37 In response, program targets have 
been reset as follows: the youth unemployment rate target for 2022 was revised to “declined to 
between 18.5% to 19.5% from the updated 2020 baseline of 21.7%. The program impact 
assessment confirms that the program’s direct impact will be on youth unemployment and youth 
NEET and will benefit women. Without the program, the male and female NEET rates would return 
to, and likely stay at, elevated rates not seen since 2010: 36.1% for females and 22.2% for males 
(Figure 2).38  Similarly, youth unemployment rates would rise to 21.9% for females and 18.3% for 
males. With the program, and assuming a quick recovery, proportionately more women will return 
to employment with their unemployment rate falling by 2.4 percentage points to 19.5% compared 
to a 1.6 percentage point decline for men. This will reduce the unemployment rate gender gap 
from 3.6 percentage points to 2.8 percentage points. Youth NEET rates exhibit a similar but less-
pronounced pattern. The female youth NEET rate is expected to recover to 30.4% and the male 
youth NEET rate to 14.7% by 2022. This equates to a decline in female youth NEET by 0.6 million 
and male youth NEET by 0.8 million. However, the gender gap for the NEET rate remains elevated 
because relatively more men are expected to enter employment and school during the recovery 
than women.39 Finally, the number of youth TVET graduates is expected to increase to 1.1 million 
from 0.8 million without the program (a 37.5% increase), with women accounting for 0.3 million or 
52.9% of this increase. These additional youth TVET graduates will produce a real wage increase 
totaling $296,250,099 by 2022, of which $157,012,553 will accrue to females.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
29.  Safeguards. In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program 
is classified category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous people’s 
safeguards. The program is not expected to have any environmental or social safeguards impacts 
within the meaning of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
 
30.  Climate  change.  The  program  supports  climate  adaptation  and  mitigation.  Of  the  
17 policy actions under subprogram 3, 12 have climate adaptation benefits, and 11 have climate 
mitigation benefits. Climate adaptation benefits are estimated at $13.53 million and mitigation 
benefits at $9.41 million.40 The passage and subsequent implementation of the Green Jobs Act 
has established a continuing framework, including fiscal incentives, to  encourage business 
enterprises to generate and sustain green jobs. 
 
31.  Poverty  and  social.  While  the  Philippines  is  on  track  to  meet  the  Sustainable 
Development Goal target of eradicating extreme poverty by 2030, there are still 17.7 million 
Filipinos who do not earn enough to afford basic food and other needs. This is because of the 
high rates of unemployment and underemployment, especially among young Filipinos. The 
program directly helps the government reduce unemployment, and youth unemployment in 
particular, by improving public employment services, enhancing skills development and training, 
and strengthening labor market policies. It will help provide the population at large, Filipino youth, 
and especially young women with better access to high-quality, long-term stable employment 
opportunities, which will drive inclusive economic growth and social stability. 
 
32.  Gender. The program is categorized as Gender Equity Theme as it aims to address 
several key gender issues. First, women have a lower labor force participation rate (47.6%) than 
men (74.8%), and a higher NEET rate (footnote 38). This is largely attributed to the additional 
responsibilities shouldered by women, including extra childcare because of school closures during 
the COVID-19 pandemic, other care giving, and domestic work. Second, women have been most 
affected by the pandemic as they account for a large share of the returned OFWs and dominate 
the services and informal sector. Third, gender-based violence in the workplace is one of the

these programs covering gender issues such as sexual and reproductive health and rights, and
